The base language used that governs how several language characteristics will behave, such as the language of the primary dictionary, and the direction and alignment of text (left-to-right or right-to-left).
In 2-D line charts, lines that extend from the highest to the lowest value in each category. High-low lines are often used in stock charts.
Any graphic you draw or insert, which can be changed and enhanced. Drawing objects include AutoShapes, curves, lines, and WordArt.

To prepare a disk for use by organizing its storage space into a collection of data "compartments", each of which can be located by the operating system so that data can be sorted and retrieved. When a previously used disk is formatted, any preexisting information on it is lost.
A diagram that is used to show foundation-based relationships.
A pigment ink/cartridge used in digital printing which provides resistance to water, fading and smudging, thus producing photographic prints with uniform gloss coverage.
A symbolic value used instead of a real value which in this case is text.
To verify that your software product is a legal copy and is installed in compliance with the Microsoft Software License Terms.
A printed version of a presentation that can include multiple slides per page and space for audience notes.
An object in relation to the class to which it belongs. For example, an object myList that belongs to a class List is an instance of the class List.
The Sheet.xlt template that you create to change the default format of new worksheets. Excel uses the template to create a blank worksheet when you add a new worksheet to a workbook.
A presence status the user can select, while signed in, to make it appear to other users that he or she is currently willing to be contacted.

A digital micropayment and loyalty service that enables efficient micropayments and prepaid purchase for cash based consumers (including kids/teens, as well as emerging and developing markets), and provides a mechanism to directly reward loyal customers.
Any token that a program can use to identify and access an object such as a device, a file, a window, or a dialog box.
To touch an item once with the tablet pen and then lift the pen quickly.
To retain a physical representation of (data or instructions) that enables them to be subsequently retrieved.
A person who uses a computer or device.
Text that does not fit within a text box. The text is hidden until it can be flowed into a new text box, or until the text box it overflows is resized to include it.
A high-speed digital technology that uses existing telephone lines to provide Internet access.
A high-speed digital technology that uses existing telephone lines to provide Internet access.
A small part, amount, or proportion of something.
A toolbar within an application used for modifying the format of the document being displayed, such as changing font size or type.

A Commerce Server application is a logical representation of an application in Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS); it appears in both Commerce Server Manager and the IIS console trees. In the IIS console tree an application is either at the root directory level of the Web site or at a subdirectory level of the Web site.
Pertaining to a type of trojan used to bypass a computer's security policies.
Information about the properties or structure of data that is not part of the values the data contains.
An association between two tables in which the primary key value of each record in the primary table corresponds to the value in the matching field or fields of many records in the related table.

A class of computer program in which one or more users interact with the computer as a form of entertainment. Computer games run the gamut from simple alphabet games for toddlers to chess, treasure hunts, war games, and simulations of world events. The games are controlled from a keyboard or with a joystick or other device and are supplied on disks, on CD-ROMs, as game cartridges, on the Internet, or as arcade devices.

A technology that allows certain devices, such as hard disks and CD or DVD drives, to transfer information directly through the computer's memory without using the computer's processor. DMA improves the performance of the device and frees the computer's processor so it can perform other tasks.

A technology that allows certain devices, such as hard disks and CD or DVD drives, to transfer information directly through the computer's memory without using the computer's processor. DMA improves the performance of the device and frees the computer's processor so it can perform other tasks.
A notice that warns that the manufacturer of the product limits liability in certain situations/uses.
A program that is used on a Web page to count the number of people that have visited that site.
To align text along the left margin.
A sticker or tag affixed to an item to provide identifying or descriptive information.
To ask someone to engage in an instant conversation.
A shape on a stencil that you use repeatedly to create drawings.

The key that is used at the end of a line or command to instruct the computer to process the command or text. In word processing programs, the Enter key is used at the end of a paragraph. Also called: Return key.

A table that relates the character codes (code point values) used by a program to keys on the keyboard or to characters on the display. This provides support for character sets and keyboard layouts for different countries or regions.
Engaging in fraud or deceptive.

A data type that stores single-precision floating-point variables as 32-bit (4-byte) floating-point numbers ranging in value from -3.402823E38 to -1.401298E-45 for negative values and 1.401298E-45 to 3.402823E38 for positive values.
The area of an application window that enables the users to perform additional tasks.
The direction a publication will be printed on a sheet of paper. You can choose either portrait, which is the taller-than-wide orientation, or landscape, which is the wider-than-tall orientation.
A part of the Purble Place game where the player has to flip a tile over to reveal a picture, and then try to find its match somewhere else.
An indicator that provides the user with information about the state of a process.
The area at the top of a Windows Journal note where you can write a title. The title appears as the suggested file name when you save the note.
A value used exactly as you see it. For example, the number 25 and the string "Hello" are both literals.
Text, graphics, and any associated annotations captured by using Snipping Tool.
A Windows tool that assists consumers in moving their data (documents and settings) to the new environment.
A line bordering the chart plot area used as a frame of reference for measurement.
A filter effect in Windows Movie Maker.
The delay that occurs while data is processed or delivered.
The .pst data file used as the main delivery location for your e-mail messages.

One of a collection of drivers that responds to the same IRPs. Layered driver describes the highest-level and lowest-level drivers in a chain of layered drivers that process the same IRPs, along with all intermediate drivers in the chain.

A feature that allows creation of mathematical formulas in documents, including the insertion of mathematical symbols inside designated "math zones" which perform automatic formatting to convert fractions, etc.
A portion of unique computer code contained in a virus. Antivirus programs search for known virus signatures to identify infected programs and files.

A feature that lets a Microsoft Outlook user who has a Microsoft Exchange e-mail account work offline, either by choice or due to a connection problem. A copy of the user's mailbox is stored on their computer and is frequently updated from the mail server. Any changes that are made while a connection to the server is not available are synchronized automatically when a connection becomes available.
In a formula, the address of a cell based on the relative position of the cell that contains the formula and the cell referred to. If you copy the formula, the reference automatically adjusts.
In a formula, the address of a cell based on the relative position of the cell that contains the formula and the cell referred to. If you copy the formula, the reference automatically adjusts.
The visual representation of a script on a Web page that you open in a Microsoft Office program.

In an organization chart, a shape that is placed below and connected to any other shape with an elbow connector. This shape is placed above any additional subordinate shapes for the particular superior shape it is attached to.
In windowing environments, such as the Apple Macintosh and Microsoft Windows, an on-screen window (enclosed work area) in which the user can create, view, or work on a document.
A feature that allows multiple design templates to be applied to a single presentation.
In a spreadsheet program, a file containing a number of related worksheets.
To programmatically disguise content to hide its substance.

A fixed-size result that is obtained by applying a one-way mathematical function (sometimes called a hash algorithm) to an arbitrary amount of data. If there is a change in the input data, the hash changes. The hash can be used in many operations, including authentication and digital signing.
A software feature that allows users to filter records in a spreadsheet or database by selecting filter criteria right in the working window rather than going through complex views and features.
A tab in Windows Media Player that enables the user to view the digital media item that is currently playing.
An image-bearing surface such as a single page or multi-page of text or picture that is passed through a scanner and has become a computer file.
The loudness of an audio signal.
Any computer designed to be moved easily.
An ordered set of rules for the purpose of implementing a messaging policy. The number of rule collections is set at design time.

A set of technologies in the Microsoft .NET Framework for building Web applications and XML Web services. ASP.NET pages execute on the server and generate markup (such as HTML, WML, or XML) that is sent to a desktop or mobile browser. ASP.NET pages use a compiled, event-driven programming model that improves performance and enables the separation of application logic and user interface. ASP.NET pages and XML Web services files created using ASP.NET contain server-side (rather than client-side) logic written in Visual Basic .NET, C# .NET, or any .NET-compatible language. Web applications and XML Web services take advantage of the features of the common language runtime, such as type safety, inheritance, language interoperability, versioning, and integrated security.
A computer printer that can print full-color output. Most color printers can also produce black-and-white output.
To confirm either that a result is correct or that a procedure or sequence of operations has been performed.
An organization's requirements for complying with privacy regulations and directives.
Any expression that evaluates to a number. The expression can be any combination of variables, constants, functions, and operators.
A set of instructions that a computer or device uses to perform a specific task, such as word processing, accounting, or data management.
A set of instructions that a computer or device uses to perform a specific task, such as word processing, accounting, or data management.
A set of instructions that a computer or device uses to perform a specific task, such as word processing, accounting, or data management.

The file on your hard disk that contains offline folders. The offline folder file has an .ost extension. You can create it automatically when you set up Outlook, or when you first make a folder available offline.

An area of storage on a hard disk. A volume is formatted by using a file system, such as NTFS, and has a drive letter assigned to it. A single hard disk can have multiple volumes. Some volumes can span multiple hard disks.

A handle (often, a tall, thin rectangle) that appears on a rebar or command band. By touching and dragging a gripper bar with a stylus or mouse, a user can reposition or resize a rebar or command band.
The act of following a link from one Web site to a site or page on another server when crawling for content.
A set of UI controls that appear in context when an object is selected and contain actions that act upon the object.
A tag that closes an element: </>. An end tag follows the syntax </Name>, where Name matches the element name declared in the start tag.
A group of related fields (columns) of information treated as a unit and arranged in a horizontal line in a table or spreadsheet.
A group of related fields (columns) of information treated as a unit and arranged in a horizontal line in a table or spreadsheet.
A bar, area, dot, slice, or other symbol in a chart that represents a single data point or value.

A hard disk that contains a small amount of solid-state nonvolatile memory which, when used as a cache, can realize significant benefits such as faster booting, extended battery life, and a more rugged PC.
A control (composed of a text box and spin button control) that allows a user to adjust a value from a limited range of possible values.

The bar that contains the 'Start' button and appears by default at the bottom of the desktop. You can click the taskbar buttons to switch between programs. You can also hide the taskbar, move it to the sides or top of the desktop, and customize it in other ways.
In an operating system, the overall structure in which files are named, stored, and organized. NTFS, FAT, and FAT32 are types of file systems.
Pertaining to an item that is only visible to the owner.
A user access option that you specify at the default Web site level or Application level in IIS. Authenticated access requires a user to have a valid account and password to access the site.
A service that returns server configuration information for a mobile device or other client using only the user's SMTP e-mail address and password.
A set of records defined by a table, a query, or an SQL expression.
An input device consisting of a set of individual keys similar to those on a typewriter. It is used to convey information from a user to a computer or data communications circuit.
An input device consisting of a set of individual keys similar to those on a typewriter. It is used to convey information from a user to a computer or data communications circuit.
The person who sets up and maintains the systems and records related to authorized users of multi-user computer networks or operating systems.
A record of synthetic, successive still images that produce an illusion of movement when played back.
A visual design surface.
Pertaining to the state of a control in which normal functionality is not available to a user.
Pertaining to the state of a control in which normal functionality is not available to a user.
Pertaining to the state of a control in which normal functionality is not available to a user.
A label that refers to the e-mail address of the person responsible for editorial content.
A logical connection created between two hosts to exchange data.

The key used by the client and server for all session key generation. The master key is used to generate the client-read key, the client-write key, the server-read key, and the server-write key. Master keys can be exported as simple key BLOBs.
Virtual folders that contain views of all e-mail items matching specific search criteria. The items remain stored in one or more Outlook folders.
A string of characters entered by a user to verify his or her identity to a network or to a local computer, device, or client, or to sign in to an account, app, and so on.
A string of characters entered by a user to verify his or her identity to a network or to a local computer, device, or client, or to sign in to an account, app, and so on.

A technology that allows Outlook and mobile devices to automatically discover and connect to the correct Exchange server without requiring the user to know the Exchange server name or other details, even if the mailbox has been moved or a server has failed.
A feature of Parental Controls that allows users to block Web sites that they don't want to view.
To move an item on the screen (1) by touching the item on a screen and then sliding the finger across the screen or (2) by pressing and holding down the left mouse button while moving the mouse.
The graphic portion of a visual output device or Surface unit.
Visual impairment that results in great reduction in vision capabilities and that cannot be aided by glasses or contact lenses. It could, however, be aided by special devices.
A service used to manage distribution lists.
The path that a specified object or text will follow as part of an animation sequence for a slide.
A data repository, in which items such as text, text boxes, pictures, tables, shapes, etc. can be stored and re-used within the same document and across multiple documents.
A device that sends, or routes, information between two networks (for example, between a home network and the Internet).
Characterized by row or column-specific formatting. Often describes rows or columns of data that use alternating colors or shading to enhance readability.

A collection of rules and data specific to a language and a geographic area. Locales include information on sorting rules, date and time formatting, numeric and monetary conventions, and character classification.

To output data and database objects to another database, spreadsheet, or file format so another database, application, or program can use the data or database objects. You can export data to a variety of supported databases, programs, and file formats.
A portable computer that allows you to write on or interact with the screen.
A portable computer that allows you to write on or interact with the screen.
Any significant occurrence in the system or an application that requires a user to be notified or an entry to be added to a log.
A number that is configured in a Private Branch eXchange (PBX) that allows a subscriber to access their Microsoft Exchange mailbox over the telephone.
The speed at which the CD drive will record the data.

Pertaining to technologies for converting textual (ASCII) information into synthetic speech output. Used in voice-processing applications requiring production of broad, unrelated, and unpredictable vocabularies, such as products in a catalog or names and addresses. This technology is appropriate when system design constraints prevent the more efficient use of speech concatenation alone.

Pertaining to technologies for converting textual (ASCII) information into synthetic speech output. Used in voice-processing applications requiring production of broad, unrelated, and unpredictable vocabularies, such as products in a catalog or names and addresses. This technology is appropriate when system design constraints prevent the more efficient use of speech concatenation alone.
An option that allows the user to specify the intervals at which an appointment or task will be repeated.
Capable of producing successful results.
Pertaining to an application on a local server or client computer, which usually hosts users for business/commercial usage.
Any characteristic of text, such as font, size, style, color, or effect such as subscript or superscript.
To join sequentially (for example, to combine the two strings "hello" and "there" into the single string "hello there").

A horizontal window at the bottom of a parent window in which an application can display various kinds of status information. The status bar can be divided into parts to display more than one type of information.
A query that uses the UNION operator to combine the results of two or more select queries.
In word processors and other applications, the feature that formats a document for printing but displays it on the video monitor rather than sending it directly to the printer.
In Windows-based computers, an account (such as a user, security group, device, or computer) that can be granted or denied access to resources.
In Windows-based computers, an account (such as a user, security group, device, or computer) that can be granted or denied access to resources.
The _ character.
The § character.
An authentication protocol that provides a mechanism for mutual authentication between a client and a server, or between one server and another, before a network connection is opened between them.

The ActiveX Database Objects (ADO) object used to contain a result set. It also exhibits cursor behavior depending on the recordset properties set by an application. ADO recordsets are mapped to OLE DB rowsets.
To propose or send in something for consideration, approval, or judgment.
A folder where a collection of PowerPoint slides is shared.
A short horizontal line used as a punctuation mark.

A domain controller that holds the infrastructure operations master role in Active Directory. The infrastructure master updates the group-to-user reference whenever group memberships change and replicates these changes across the domain. At any time, the infrastructure master role can be assigned to only one domain controller in each domain.
A set of features that provides a programming interface for accessing Microsoft Exchange data through the Client Access server role by using Web services.
A graphic that indicates follow-up action is required, or otherwise identifies an important item.
A feature that uses a minimum amount of data to display the general layout of a report.
A World Wide Web Consortium specification that describes the structure of dynamic HTML and XML documents in a way that allows them to be manipulated through a Web browser.
A World Wide Web Consortium specification that describes the structure of dynamic HTML and XML documents in a way that allows them to be manipulated through a Web browser.
The certification authority which issued the certificate to the subject.

Appears to the left of a meeting or appointment (or all the way around the item when selected), indicating time status as free, tentative, busy, out of office, or no information available. Visible only in Day and Work Week view.
A computer-wide code cache that stores assemblies specifically installed to be shared by many applications on the computer.
To include an external document, a file, or an executable program with an e-mail message.
To turn a setting off or to remove a value.
A security feature that allows for greater granularity and customization of user permissions.
To eliminate or temporarily suppress the sound produced by a device, such as a computer or digital media device. A device in such a state has a volume level of zero.
A service that provides access to data and objects in a directory or network environment.

A graphic file format that is supported by some World Wide Web browsers. PNG supports variable transparency of images (alpha channels) and control of image brightness on different computers (gamma correction). PNG files are compressed bitmaps.
A toolbar that you create for your application.
Strength exerted; might.

The PivotTable report that supplies the source data to the PivotChart report. It is created automatically when you create a new PivotChart report. When you change the layout of either report, the other also changes.

Software components developed by Apple for creating, editing, publishing, and viewing multimedia content. QuickTime, which supports video, animation, graphics, 3-D, VR (virtual reality), MIDI, music, sound, and text, has been part of the Mac OS since version 7 of the operating system and is used in many Macintosh applications. Windows applications can also run QuickTime files but require the installation of special player software. QuickTime is often used on the Web to provide Web pages with video and animation. Most Web browsers support plug-ins for running these types of files. QuickTime is also part of the new MPEG-4 specification.
To add a check to a check box to specify a desired feature or option.
A device that is added to the base computer system to increase functionality, such as audio, networking, graphics, or SCSI controller.
A device that is added to the base computer system to increase functionality, such as audio, networking, graphics, or SCSI controller.
Of, pertaining to, or being a device that does not require support from another device or system, for example, a computer that is not connected to a network.
A feature that allows users to preview, edit or delete building blocks in a variety of galleries, and insert them into the current document.
An internal NT file system (NTFS) structure in which the file system maintains the state for an open instance of a directory file.
An internal NT file system (NTFS) structure in which the file system maintains the state for an open instance of a directory file.

A reference to a range of cells instead of a single cell that is calculated like a single cell. If cell C10 contains the formula =B5: B15*5, Excel multiplies the value in cell B10 by 5 because cells B10 and C10 are in the same row.
A Microsoft Web site that provides customers with access to a database of articles written by Microsoft Support professionals.
A Microsoft Web site that provides customers with access to a database of articles written by Microsoft Support professionals.
A Microsoft Web site that provides customers with access to a database of articles written by Microsoft Support professionals.

A movie clip that plays when the user opens a Web page, or when the pointer rests on a movie image, or in both instances, depending on the object's settings. Not all Web browsers support inline movies.
A derivative of the file allocation table (FAT) file system. FAT32 supports smaller cluster sizes and larger volumes than FAT, which results in more efficient space allocation on FAT32 volumes.

A unique set of letters or numbers that identifies a wireless network. For a computer or device to connect to a wireless network, it must supply that network’s SSID. An SSID can be up to 32 characters.

A unique set of letters or numbers that identifies a wireless network. For a computer or device to connect to a wireless network, it must supply that network’s SSID. An SSID can be up to 32 characters.

Vertical lines appearing next to text that has been added, deleted, or changed by using tracked changes. You can specify that changed lines appear to the left or right of text. You can also hide changed lines.
A message that appears in a newsgroup, public folder, or other forum, such as Facebook or Twitter, accessible by a number of individuals.
A message that appears in a newsgroup, public folder, or other forum, such as Facebook or Twitter, accessible by a number of individuals.

The meaning of data as it is intended to be interpreted by people. Data consists of facts, which become information when they are seen in context and convey meaning to people. Computers process data without any understanding of what the data represents.

The meaning of data as it is intended to be interpreted by people. Data consists of facts, which become information when they are seen in context and convey meaning to people. Computers process data without any understanding of what the data represents.
To safeguard a resource from attack or loss.
A filter effect in Windows Movie Maker.
A hierarchy of folders in the Exchange store very similar in structure to the standard file system. A single folder can contain child folders, which, in turn, can contain other child folders.
A server that is dedicated to creating and updating context indexes.
Pertaining to a formatting style in which characters are crossed out by horizontal line.
A feature that notifies a user when there is a change to posted content, workflow status, or when other user-defined criteria are met.
A list of the last 10 files you jumped to in the current program session using hyperlinks.

A portion of a computer's random access memory (RAM) set aside for temporarily holding information read from disk. A disk cache does not hold entire files, as does a RAM disk (a portion of memory that acts as if it were a disk drive). Instead, a disk cache is used to hold information that either has recently been requested from disk or has previously been written to disk. If the required information remains in a disk cache, access time is considerably faster than if the program must wait for the disk drive mechanism to fetch the information from disk.
A non-printing line or point that can be used to help position or align objects or text.

A directory service model and a set of Component Object Model (COM) interfaces. ADSI enables Windows applications and Active Directory clients to access several network directory services, including Active Directory.
A language used to address parts of an XML document. XPath also provides basic facilities for manipulation of strings, numbers, and Boolean values.
A language used to address parts of an XML document. XPath also provides basic facilities for manipulation of strings, numbers, and Boolean values.
A value that is automatically entered in a field or control when you add a new record. You can either accept the default value or override it by typing a value.
The process of reconciling the differences between data stored in one location and a copy of the same data stored in another location.
The process of reconciling the differences between data stored in one location and a copy of the same data stored in another location.
A calendar item in the Exchange store. Appointments do not include other people or resources.
The process of recording actions that take place on a computer, network, or system.
A connection between an element in a hypertext document, such as a word, phrase, symbol, or image, and a different element in the document or in another location, a webpage, file, or script.
A parameter in the Perlin Noise function which is used to scale the amount of force from the vector field that is applied to the images.
Content has been hashed but could not be verified as valid against the signature.
The distance between the cells of a table or workbook.
A table, chart, graphic, equation, or other form of information.
A column chart subtype that shows the relationship of individual items to the whole, comparing the contribution of each value to a total across categories.
One of the four card locations in the upper-right corner of the screen.
A document that contains the header row (or header record) to be used with the data source specified for a mail-merge main document.
A title animation in Windows Movie Maker.
A part of a form, report, or data access page such as a header, footer, or detail section.
A fraction that is written vertically with the numerator on top and denominator below, with no fraction bar between them.

A display format, like that of Windows, that represents a program's functions with graphic images such as buttons and icons. GUIs enable a user to perform operations and make choices by pointing and clicking with a mouse.

A display format, like that of Windows, that represents a program's functions with graphic images such as buttons and icons. GUIs enable a user to perform operations and make choices by pointing and clicking with a mouse.

A display format, like that of Windows, that represents a program's functions with graphic images such as buttons and icons. GUIs enable a user to perform operations and make choices by pointing and clicking with a mouse.
The portion of the e-mail address that appears to the left of the @ symbol.
The portion of the e-mail address that appears to the left of the @ symbol.
One or more ranges of cells that you designate to print when you don't want to print the entire worksheet. If a worksheet includes a print area, only the print area is printed.
To make a change to an existing file or document.
A paper size of 95.25mm x 171.45 mm.
A new type of ScreenTip that is larger and can contain more detailed information, including graphics.
A new type of ScreenTip that is larger and can contain more detailed information, including graphics.
Of, pertaining to, or characterized by non-capital letters.
Information stored in the prologue of an XML document. This information is passed through the XML parser to any application that uses the XML document.
The condition of a user that can be displayed to the user's contacts to communicate whether the user is currently online and available, offline and unavailable, and so on.
A proprietary protocol to provide remote display and input capabilities over network connections for Windows®-based applications between two computers.
A proprietary protocol to provide remote display and input capabilities over network connections for Windows®-based applications between two computers.
Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of an action or operation that takes place based on whether or not a certain condition is true.

Application software that gathers data from the user, prepares it for the server, and issues a request to the server. The client presents data received from the server to the user through its own user interface.
An item in the Exchange store that represents an appointment, a meeting, a meeting request, or an event. It can identify the place, resources, recurrence, and attendees involved at a discrete time.
Content or links that an administrator associates with specific keywords, and that are displayed prominently in search results when a query contains one of those keywords.
A permission setting that permits a person or domain to add the user to contact lists, see the user's status, or send instant messages to the user.
To put into use.
A UI element that ends a user session or exits a service.
The person in charge of managing a computer. The administrator is responsible for installing software, assigning passwords, and managing files.
The person in charge of managing a computer. The administrator is responsible for installing software, assigning passwords, and managing files.
The stylistic attributes of a font — such as bold, italic, and underline.

A type of managed folder that is created by an Exchange administrator and placed in a user’s mailbox for messaging records management (MRM) purposes. The retention and journaling of messages in managed custom folders are controlled by managed content settings that are applied to the folder.
A list of users, accounts, Web sites, etc. that are permitted to perform certain actions on a network.
A list of users, accounts, Web sites, etc. that are permitted to perform certain actions on a network.
A slide template that defines default formatting or the position of placeholders for one or more slides in a presentation.
An operating unit whose managers are accountable for budgeted and actual expenditures.
The set of rules on a computer and a portable device that allow digital media files and other information to be synchronized.
A context menu that enables the user to preview the contents of a file with the Office Preview Handler (OPH) in Outlook (either documents attached to email or SharePoint documents in Outlook).

The primary access protocol for Active Directory. LDAP is an industry-standard protocol, established by the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF), that allows users to query and update information in a directory service. Active Directory supports both LDAP version 2 and LDAP version 3.

The primary access protocol for Active Directory. LDAP is an industry-standard protocol, established by the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF), that allows users to query and update information in a directory service. Active Directory supports both LDAP version 2 and LDAP version 3.
A filter effect in Windows Movie Maker.

Adds preset visual effects to text on slides. Ranging from subtle to exciting, each scheme usually includes an effect for the slide title and an effect that is applied to bullets or paragraphs on a slide.
A brief content of a larger document.
A standard system control that initiates a command.
A standard system control that initiates a command.
A feature in Windows that allows users to access and manage printers, multi-function printers, digital cameras and scanners.
To prevent another user from initiating a conversation and from viewing your presence or other information, such as your personal information.
The list of answers to a search request that match the search criteria specified by the user.

The part of an agreement that defines the business process that is used, your role, your partner's role, and the policies or parameters that are used in that relationship along with documentation, such as a list of business and legal terms.
A listing or document selected as the best recommendation in the Site Directory.
A list in which each item or block of text is preceded by a bullet.
A temporary storage place for deleted files. The user can use it to retrieve files deleted in error. These deleted files are not actually removed from the hard disk until the recycle bin is emptied.

A list of domain names and e-mail addresses that you want to receive messages from. E-mail addresses in Contacts and in the Global Address Book are included in this list by default. People you sent messages to will be added to the list.
A field size or data type that can hold positive integer numbers ranging from 0 to 255.

An application that runs on a Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) managed device. The agent application is the object of management activities. A computer running SNMP agent software is also sometimes referred to as an agent.
An optical storage medium for digital data.
An optical storage medium for digital data.
A personal or work-related project, assignment, or errand to be tracked through to completion.
A personal or work-related project, assignment, or errand to be tracked through to completion.
A secondary window that allows users to perform a command, asks users a question, or provides users with information or progress feedback.
A block of two or more cells in a spreadsheet.
A rectangular area on a computer screen in which programs and content appear.
The number of video frames displayed per second. Higher frame rates generally produce smoother movement in the picture.
The number of video frames displayed per second. Higher frame rates generally produce smoother movement in the picture.
The number of video frames displayed per second. Higher frame rates generally produce smoother movement in the picture.
The ability of a Web server to support more than one Internet address and more than one home page.

The recognizer specific part of the shape trainer. Typically every recognizer claiming to support shape personalization must supply a Shape Client DLL. All the Microsoft Latin recognizers will all use the same Shape Client.
A network status that indicates a client is not connected to a server.
The { character.
A small x or other sign that appears in the check box if the option represented by the box is selected.
To retrieve a writable copy of a file or project from a source repository. This locks the file for editing to prevent others from overwriting or editing it inadvertently.
A floating task pane that allows users to view and customize specific paragraph and text style properties.
Add-in software that provides partially localized user interfaces for particular computer programs in languages not supported by localized versions of those programs.
Add-in software that provides partially localized user interfaces for particular computer programs in languages not supported by localized versions of those programs.
A cookie that is deleted at the end of the browser session.

A folder on a public server that people can use to share information, such as work information, discussions, contacts, tasks, and classified ads. Access permissions determine who can view and alter the folder and to what extent.
A number that is not a whole number, such as ½ (vulgar fraction) or 0.5 (decimal fraction), formed by dividing one quantity into another.
A file containing digitized audio, such as voice or music.

A startup process that begins with turning on the computer's power. Typically, a cold boot involves some basic hardware checking by the system, after which the operating system is loaded from disk into memory.

A startup process that begins with turning on the computer's power. Typically, a cold boot involves some basic hardware checking by the system, after which the operating system is loaded from disk into memory.
The command interpreter that is used to pass commands to the operating system.

The device on which images generated by the computer's video adapter are displayed. The term monitor usually refers to a video display and its housing. The monitor is attached to the video adapter by a cable.

A group of one or more COM objects in a process. A COM object lives in exactly one apartment, in the sense that its methods can legally be directly called only by a thread that belongs to that apartment. Any other thread that wants to call the object must go through a proxy.
An index entry that falls under a more general heading. For example, the index entry "planets" could have the subentries "Mars" and "Venus."

Related data points that are plotted in a chart. Each data series in a chart has a unique color or pattern and is represented in the chart legend. You can plot one or more data series in a chart. Pie charts have only one data series.
A view of a document as it will appear on the printed page.
Colors that are directly next to each other on the color wheel. Each color has two analogous colors (one on each side of it).
A grouping of one or more URLs served by a worker process.

A fixed-disk file system that organizes the disk into volumes, rather than partitions and logical drives. HPFS supports long, mixed-case filenames and extended attributes, and implements several levels of caching, for improved operating-system performance. The IBM OS/2 operating system supports HPFS.
A disk directory in which an SMTP service can deposit incoming mail messages.
A disk directory in which an SMTP service can deposit incoming mail messages.
A library that provide content types with common properties, and enhanced views to find and preview rich media, also called digital assets.
A group in the data source that can occur more than once. Controls such as repeating sections and repeating tables are bound to repeating groups.

In operating systems and database applications, a situation in which two or more processes cannot continue because each process is waiting for resources to be freed by the continuation of the other process.

A data type that stores a signed, exact numeric value described as the number of digits appearing before and after the decimal point, with a maximum of 29 total digits. All possible digits cannot be represented if you are using the maximum number of digits.
The process of rewriting parts of a file to contiguous sectors on a hard disk to increase the speed of access and retrieval.
The blank area between two or more columns of text or between two facing pages in a publication.
In a 2-D chart, the area bounded by the axes, including all data series. In a 3-D chart, the area bounded by the axes, including the data series, category names, tick-mark labels, and axis titles.

A small piece of code that can be transported over the Internet and executed on the recipient's machine. The term is especially used to refer to such programs as they are embedded in line as objects in HTML documents on the World Wide Web.
The alternate calendar that is selected from within Outlook. The secondary calendar appears when dual calendar support is enabled.

A software package that replaces an existing version of a product with a newer and/or more powerful or sophisticated version of the same product. The upgrade process typically leaves existing customer data and preferences intact while replacing the existing software with the newer version.

A software package that replaces an existing version of a product with a newer and/or more powerful or sophisticated version of the same product. The upgrade process typically leaves existing customer data and preferences intact while replacing the existing software with the newer version.
The condition of a field, record, recordset, or database that makes it read-only to all users except the user currently modifying it.
The rules governing the formation of a command-line statement, including the order in which a command must be typed, and the elements that follow the command.
A query (SQL statement) that creates a new table and then creates records (rows) in it by copying records from an existing table.
A query (SQL statement) that creates a new table and then creates records (rows) in it by copying records from an existing table.
Audio, video, images, text, or any other information that is contained in a digital media file or stream.

A set of components and services that enable users to access their Exchange mailboxes through the application Outlook Web Access and the protocols Exchange ActiveSync, Post Office Protocol version 3 (POP3), and Internet Message Access Protocol 4rev1 (IMAP4). The Client Access server role also includes Web services that are used by other Exchange 2007 server roles.
A window that you can display when a data access page is open in Design view.
A combination of identifiers, which together define Internet Protocol security (IPsec), that protects communication between sender and receiver.
A combination of identifiers, which together define Internet Protocol security (IPsec), that protects communication between sender and receiver.
A label that is printed with a recipient's address and is used to mail or ship an item.
A label that is printed with a recipient's address and is used to mail or ship an item.

The basic element that holds information in Outlook (similar to a file in other programs). Items include e-mail messages, appointments, contacts, tasks, journal entries, notes, posted items, and documents.

The basic element that holds information in Outlook (similar to a file in other programs). Items include e-mail messages, appointments, contacts, tasks, journal entries, notes, posted items, and documents.
In operation; operating, working.
In a mail-merge operation, the document that contains the text and graphics that are the same for each version of the merged document, for example, the return address or salutation in a form letter.
The structure or organization of data in a file.
The structure or organization of data in a file.
A feature of Windows that defines and manages a standard format for application setup and installation, and tracks components such as groups of files, registry entries, and shortcuts.
The time period during which a product or service will remain functional before the user or customer must license, register, renew, or otherwise (re)activate their product or subscription.
The time period during which a product or service will remain functional before the user or customer must license, register, renew, or otherwise (re)activate their product or subscription.
An organization with more than 1000 employees and more than 500 personal computers.
An organization with more than 1000 employees and more than 500 personal computers.
An organization with more than 1000 employees and more than 500 personal computers.
Text that does not display in the normal view of a document's content.
A feature that allows users to see and interact with E-mail messages and their attachments side by side in the reading pane.
A page that presents a categorical view of select Help content that the user can browse. Depending on the edition, multiple How Do I pages might be available for use.
A filter effect in Windows Movie Maker.

A font display technology that dramatically improves font display resolution so that letters on the computer screen appear smooth, not jagged. ClearType dramatically improves the readability of text on color LCD monitors with a digital interface, such as those found in laptops and high-quality flat-panel desktop displays.
A space that is used to prevent multiple words from breaking if they fall at the end of a line.
A domain controller that has been assigned one or more special roles in an Active Directory domain.

A fundamental data type that holds double-precision floating-point numbers. It's stored as a 64-bit number ranging in value from approximately -1.797E308 to -4.940E-324 (negative), from 4.94E-324 to 1.797E308 (positive), and 0.

A precompiled collection of SQL statements and optional control-of-flow statements stored under a name and processed as a unit. They are stored in an SQL database and can be run with one call from an application.

A worksheet view that displays the areas to be printed and the locations of page breaks. The area to be printed is displayed in white, automatic page breaks appear as dashed lines, and manual page breaks appear as solid lines.
A set of software functionality designed to solve a specific problem or to provide a new functionality to the user.
A field that stores hyperlink addresses.
Files that are used to help detect harmful or unwanted software and to prevent it from installing or running on your computer.

A button on the message toolbar that compares the names in the To, Cc, and Bcc boxes against the names in the Address Book and against those contact folders that you've specified as Outlook Address Books.

A user interface element that provides users with a quick and easy way to navigate across a large group of opened Web pages by providing the user with a visual representation of all of the opened thumbnails. Through this visualization, the user can easily spot and select a desired thumbnail.
A "container" for a set of separate files (or subdocuments). You can use a master document to set up and manage a multipart document, such as a book with several chapters.

A string that is used to identify a user or entity to an operating system, directory service, or distributed system. For example, in Windows® integrated authentication, a login name uses the form "DOMAIN\username."
A type of column that displays the results of mathematical or logical operations or expressions instead of stored data.
An audio CD that contains both audio and other multimedia content.
The speed at which binary digits are transmitted.
A flowchart used to compare current and ideal processes, and to understand how the steps in a process work together.
To change a program in order to be able to run it on a different computer.
A feature that allows you to set up your computer so that when you insert a CD or DVD, it will play automatically and you won't have to select your preferences every time.
A list in which each item or block of text is preceded by a number.

A document area that contains a range of text distinct from other areas of text in a document. For example, if a document includes body text, footnotes, and headers, it contains a main text story, footnotes story, and headers story.

An authentication method that prompts the user for a user name and a password, also called credentials, which are hashed with other data before being transmitted over the network. Digest authentication is available only on domains that have domain controllers that are running Microsoft Windows Server operating systems.
Personal configurations of a program or operating system.
The main rule for a site that includes or excludes content from the content index.
The – character, based on the width of an uppercase N and used primarily as a connecting element, especially with numbers.
The – character, based on the width of an uppercase N and used primarily as a connecting element, especially with numbers.
A text file containing code to apply semantics such as page layout specifications to published content.
A vertical area along the left edge of the document window that displays the name of the paragraph style that is applied to each paragraph.
A serial communications port used to connect a device, such as a modem, printer, or mobile device, to a computer.
A serial communications port used to connect a device, such as a modem, printer, or mobile device, to a computer.
A serial communications port used to connect a device, such as a modem, printer, or mobile device, to a computer.
The formal name for Excel 12 file format. The Excel XML Format has an open, royalty-free specification, and is the technology licensed to external parties.

A type of object that has an e-mail address on a domain in the organization, but the object does not have a mailbox in the domain at which to receive messages. The object appears in the global address list, which allows other people in the organization to easily locate or send a message to that person, but the administrator does not need to manage an unnecessary mailbox. Contacts, users, and even folders can be mail-enabled.

descripGrp.descrip: A database object that stores data in records (rows) and fields (columns). The data is usually about a particular category of things, such as employees or orders.
A type of CD on which files can be copied, erased, and replaced.
A type of CD on which files can be copied, erased, and replaced.
A legal agreement between Microsoft and the user, with regard to the terms of use and transfer of software.
For local area networks (LANs), a device that is connected to the network and is capable of communicating with other network devices.
The † character.
An information structure that precedes and identifies the information that follows.
Used by Microsoft Exchange to identify, locate, and open a form.
A function of some Web browsers that allows users to surf and view multiple pages by loading Web sites into sections (or tabs) of one page, rather than multiple pages.
A notification bar warning the user about data that is blocked in the loaded file. Trust Bars can be for information only (non-actionable) or actionable.
Of or pertaining to documents, data, software, or hardware that existed prior to a certain time.
A character with a non-zero width.
A rectangular array of pixels applied to a visual object.
A common drop-down menu that includes general purpose commands for editing objects displayed within a window, such as Cut, Copy, and Paste.
In Task Manager, the current working set of a process, in kilobytes. The current working set is the number of pages currently resident in memory.
A title animation in Windows Movie Maker.
Any ink that you add to a file that is not recognized as handwriting.

A feature or add-in for Outlook that enables small business owners to list business contacts, accounts, and opportunities, and to perform several tasks related to managing and tracking information about the business.
The structure or appearance of a unit of data, such as a field, or text in a message body.
The structure or appearance of a unit of data, such as a field, or text in a message body.
A natural number, zero, or the negative of a natural number.
To transfer a copy of a file from a local computer to a remote computer by means of a modem or network.
A feature that enables mobile devices, such as cellular phones, to access some SharePoint services.
