descripGrp.descrip: The user role that is assigned to a user account, which determines the options that are visible to that user and the tasks that the user can perform in the management interface for Exchange Labs.
A service that enables customers to implement Windows Live communication services within their own personal domains.
A disk image provided for use in repairing or reinstalling an installation of Windows.
A recognition feature that helps increase input speed and reduce effort by providing users with word completion and next word prediction alternates as the user is writing/typing.
An extension of the conventional touch input feature to allow multiple fingers touching the computer or device screen at the same time.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of one or two fingers moving in the same direction, parallel to each other.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of one or two fingers moving in the same direction, parallel to each other.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of two fingers moving in opposite directions (-> <- or <- ->).
A multi-touch gesture that consists of two fingers moving around a center point or one finger moving around a finger that is not moving.
An engine that specifically recognizes and processes touch input and multi-touch input as commands.
The worldwide collection of networks and gateways that use the TCP/IP suite of protocols to communicate with one another.
A collection of computing resources such as programs and virtual desktops that enable a user to accomplish a set of related tasks.

The entity that offers a remote workspace, typically the IT department of the user’s employer, a business partner or vendor, or less commonly, a commercial application service provider. The publisher may use a digital certificate to represent its identity and use it to sign the remote resource files (e.g. RDP files) and the workspace description (e.g. Web Service feed).
Silent and unexpected process termination by the process itself or by another application.
To shut down a core processor for power saving purpose.
To reopen a core processor that had been parked for power saving purpose.
A feature of Windows Media Player that allows users to remove gaps between tracks that they burn to audio CDs.
Existing in reference to the removal of silences or clicks between tracks when they are burnt to an audio CD or when they are played back from the CD.
A unique identifier made from four otherwise separate pieces of information. For example, a color can be specified by a black, yellow, magenta and cyan quad.
Any information (e.g. account numbers, sensitive data, etc.) with a title and some free-form text that can be stored in a secure manner in a personal vault.
To make an object, such as a file, accessible.
A feature that replicates the animation associated with a source object to one or more target objects.
An abstract grouping of similar animation effects.
An effect that a user can apply to an image to achieve a specific artistic look.
A visual representation of an audio signal over time.
An image editing feature that allows a user to isolate the foreground portion of an image and make the background transparent.
An option that removes narrations and laser pointer gestures or timings from a presentation or from a specific slide.
A set of cryptographic algorithms specified by the US National Security Agency to provide an interoperable standard for government and industry.
The ability of software to support customer-preferred algorithms for encryption, hashing, entropy and digital signatures.
The ability of software to support customer-preferred algorithms for encryption, hashing, entropy and digital signatures.
The portion of InfoPath used to design forms.
To remove a user's changes from the Microsoft Office Document Cache without deleting the file on the server or removing the latest version downloaded from the server from the Office Document Cache.
A security feature that validates files before allowing them to be loaded by the application, in order to protect against file format vulnerabilities.
A feature that allows end users and IT admins to control which file types and versions can be opened and saved in the application.

A feature that allows the user to superimpose a dot over a presentation and control its position with the mouse. The appearance of the dot is similar to that of a traditional laser pointer, and it is broadcast to all presentation viewers and can be recorded into video (Save to Video).
An option that initiates an e-mail response addressed to all of the recipients on the To or Cc lines of the original message.
An option that initiates an e-mail response addressed to all of the recipients on the To or Cc lines of the original message.
A mode of Windows Photo Viewer which consists of a top level window displaying one photograph at a time, with navigation controls.
A mode of Windows Photo Viewer which displays full-screen slide shows for photos.
A recordable media (such as CD-RW) to which you can only write once without reformatting.
A recordable media to which you can write several times without reformatting.
A feature that is added to the Microsoft Office Compatibility Pack to open Word, Excel, and PowerPoint binary format files and securely convert them to the Office 2007 file formats.
A feature that makes Outlook auto-complete lists available through the default Exchange mailbox.

A common credential store and interface that is used to save and manage user credentials, such as user names and passwords, so you can easily log on to Web sites and connect to other resources, such as computers.
A set of credentials that users can create, store and manage in Credential Manager.
A type of vault that contains Web passwords and secure notes that you can place on a USB flash drive and use on another computer.
A control in a form that consists of an actionable image. At run time the user can click the image to run rules or actions similar to a button.
To make final small changes to improve hardware or software performance; to fine-tune a nearly complete product.
A Web Part that displays a browser-enabled InfoPath form.
A SharePoint Server service that maintains temporary state information for InfoPath Forms Services.
A feature that updates absolute URLs in form templates associated with SharePoint Form Libraries (i.e., InfoPath XSNs) as well as Universal Data Connection files.

A feature that enables presenters in the rich client to broadcast a slide show to remote viewers watching in a Web browser. Throughout the presentation, the remote attendees will see the current slide being shown by the presenter.
A labeled group of consecutive slides that helps the user navigate and organize presentations.
A labeled group of consecutive slides that helps the user navigate and organize presentations.
A feature that allows the user to insert the contents of an open window or a screen clipping into the current document without the need to utilize external applications.
A feature that makes automatic versions of user documents during each autosave operation and allows the user to revert to previous copies of the document with ease.
A feature that alerts users to potential issues with e-mail recipients before the message is sent.
To establish a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetooth–enabled devices.
To make a single file out of a set of files using a program such as compress, gzip, or PKZIP.
A unique, persistent identifier assigned to a document or other item in SharePoint Server that allows it to be referenced and retrieved regardless of its location.
A URL that is based on a query using the Document ID rather than the physical location of the item.
A special type of folder that enables users to manage a deliverable or work product spanning multiple documents as a single entity.
A SharePoint document library where users can upload files that are then routed automatically to the correct library or folder in the site based upon rules defined by the site administrator.
A feature that displays a definition or translation of a word or piece of text in a ScreenTip when the pointer is moved over the selection.

To copy driver binaries, install services, and add registry keys for one or more drivers from a driver package onto a system, without the context of a specific device. A system can be booted from reflected drivers, however full device installation may still be required in order to enable full driver functionality.
A Windows feature that enables users to share pictures, music, videos, documents, and printers with other people on a home network.
An abstract grouping of similar transition effects.

A full-page UI view that exposes file-level functionality in Office applications. This is a companion feature to the Office Ribbon and helps users discover and use the features that fall outside of the authoring features on the Ribbon.

A full-page UI view that exposes file-level functionality in Office applications. This is a companion feature to the Office Ribbon and helps users discover and use the features that fall outside of the authoring features on the Ribbon.

A full-page UI view that exposes file-level functionality in Office applications. This is a companion feature to the Office Ribbon and helps users discover and use the features that fall outside of the authoring features on the Ribbon.
A digital distribution provider of games such as MSN Games, Yahoo Games, Steam, Stardock, GameTap, and so on.
A file used as part of a testing process to check the validity or correctness of a program or procedure.
A feature that helps users of some Office applications to improve the accessibility of documents they create.
An instant message that is transmitted while the sender or recipient is offline.
The helper program that can store sign-in information for multiple Windows Live IDs.
A feature that offers improved security by loading a document in a read-only view, rather than in the full editor, for scenarios that pose a greater potential security risk.
A package containing everything you need to show one or many PowerPoint presentations on another computer. This package can be saved to a folder or burned to a CD.

A feature that allows the user to indicate that a document is trusted, and therefore can be opened without security notifications, so long as the filepath and creation time of the document remain unchanged.
A list that displays someone's recent activity on Windows Live.
The contact picture label that indicates someone has been invited to do something, but has not responded yet.
The link to the webpage where a user manages photos and albums.
The link to the main landing/start page on Windows Live.
The process of establishing a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetooth–enabled devices.
A Windows library that allows users to store, manage and share all their recorded TV items.
The use of Web sites and services that provide enhanced information and interaction capabilities with regard to people and resources.
A feature that allows you to preview the appearance of a formatting option or command before actually applying it to selected text or objects.
The process of dynamically rearranging a hierarchy of SharePoint sites, typically used during a migration.
The process of dynamically rearranging a hierarchy of SharePoint sites, typically used during a migration.
The process of finding content related to an investigation, litigation, or audit so that it can be properly tracked and maintained.
A stage in a retention policy, consisting of an event-action pair.
A Windows service that provides software licensing activation and notification.
An extensible platform component for decoding/encoding digital images and performing common transforms.
A Windows feature that provides a direct connection to a corporate network for people working outside of the office. It is a superior alternative to VPN.
A PC (desktop and beyond) search platform that allows search of the local hard drive plus network locations like SharePoint sites and the Internet.
A set of attributes that define a user's access to a given service or application.
To break a connection.
Pertaining to something, such as a signal or connection, that is not unbroken but occurs at periodic or occasional intervals.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression, a timeline, or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. Works well for illustrating both Level 1 and Level 2 text.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show groups of information or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. Emphasizes the interaction or relationships among the groups of information.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show either related or contrasting concepts with some connection, such as opposing forces. The first two lines of Level 1 text are used for text in the arrows. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to compare or show the relationship between two ideas. Each of the first two lines of Level 1 text corresponds to text at the top of one side of the center point. Emphasizes Level 2 text, which is limited to four shapes on each side of the center point. The balance tips towards the side with the most shapes containing Level 2 text. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. Maximizes both horizontal and vertical display space for shapes.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show non-sequential or grouped blocks of information. Maximizes both horizontal and vertical display space for shapes.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression; a timeline; sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow; or to emphasize movement or direction. Level 1 text appears inside an arrow shape while Level 2 text appears below the arrow shapes.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to represent a continuing sequence of stages, tasks, or events in a circular flow. Emphasizes the stages or steps rather than the connecting arrows or flow. Works best with Level 1 text only.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show the relationship of components to a whole in quadrants. The first four lines of Level 1 text appear in the quadrants. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show how individual parts form a whole. The first seven lines of Level 1 text correspond to the evenly distributed wedge or pie shapes. The top Level 1 text shape appears outside of the rest of the pie for emphasis. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show proportional, interconnected, or hierarchical relationships with the largest component on the bottom and narrowing up. Level 1 text appears in the pyramid segments and Level 2 text appears in shapes alongside each segment.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show the relationship to a central idea in a cycle. The first line of Level 1 text corresponds to the central shape, and its Level 2 text corresponds to the surrounding circular shapes. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show containment, gradations, or hierarchical relationships. The first five lines of Level 1 text are associated with a circle. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow, or to show timeline information. Works well with both Level 1 and Level 2 text.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show overlapping or interconnected relationships. The first seven lines of Level 1 text correspond with a circle. If there are four or fewer lines of Level 1 text, the text is inside the circles. If there are more than four lines of Level 1 text, the text is outside of the circles. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show non-sequential or grouped blocks of information. The small circular shapes are designed to contain pictures. Works well for illustrating both Level 1 and Level 2 text. Maximizes both horizontal and vertical display space for shapes.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to represent a continuing sequence of stages, tasks, or events in a circular flow. Emphasizes the stages or steps rather than the connecting arrows or flow.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression through several processes that make up an overall workflow. Also works for illustrating contrasting processes. The Level 1 text corresponds to the first arrow shape on the left, while the Level 2 text corresponds to horizontal sub-steps for each shape that contains Level 1 text.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a long or non-linear sequence or steps in a task, process, or workflow. Works best with Level 1 text only. Maximizes both horizontal and vertical display space for shapes.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression, a timeline, or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow, or to emphasize movement or direction. Can be used to emphasize information in the starting shape. Works best with Level 1 text only.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a timeline or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. Works best with Level 1 text because each line of Level 1 text appears inside the arrow shape. Level 2 text appears outside the arrow shape.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. Works best with minimal Level 1 and Level 2 text.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to represent a continuing sequence of stages, tasks, or events in a circular flow. Emphasizes the connection between all components. Works best with Level 1 text only.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show groups of interconnected information. The circular shapes are designed to contain pictures.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show ideas or concepts that converge to a central point. Works best with Level 1 text only.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show relationships of concepts or components to a central idea in a cycle. The first line of Level 1 text corresponds to the central circular shape and the lines of Level 2 text correspond to the surrounding rectangular shapes. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show two opposing ideas or concepts. Each of the first two lines of Level 1 text corresponds to an arrow and works well with Level 2 text. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show the relationship to a central idea in a cyclical progression. Each of the first four lines of Level 1 text corresponds to a wedge or pie shape, and Level 2 text appears in a rectangular shape to the side of the wedge or pie shape. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used with large amounts of Level 2 text to show a progression through stages.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show ideas or concepts that progress outward from a central source. Works best with Level 1 text only.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show relationships to a central idea in a cycle. The first Level 1 line of text corresponds to the central circular shape. Emphasizes the surrounding circles rather than the central idea. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show sequential steps or tasks that depict a plan or result. The last Level 1 line of text appears after the equals sign (=).Works best with Level 1 text only.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show the filtering of information or how parts merge into a whole. Emphasizes the final outcome. Can contain up to four lines of Level 1 text; the last of these four Level 1 text lines appears below the funnel and the other lines correspond to a circular shape. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show interlocking ideas. Each of the first three lines of Level 1 text corresponds to a gear shape, and their corresponding Level 2 text appears in rectangles next to the gear shape. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show the placement of concepts along two axes. Emphasizes the individual components rather than the whole. The first four lines of Level 1 text appear in the quadrants. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show groups and sub-groups of information, or steps and sub-steps in a task, process, or workflow. Level 1 text corresponds to the top-level horizontal shapes, and Level 2 text corresponds to vertical sub-steps under each related top-level shape. Works well for emphasizing sub-groups or sub-steps, hierarchical information, or multiple lists of information.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show hierarchical relationships progressing from top to bottom.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show hierarchical relationships progressing across groups. Can also be used to group or list information.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show non-sequential or grouped lists of information. Works well with large amounts of text. All text has the same level of emphasis, and direction is not implied.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show hierarchical relationships progressing horizontally. Works well for decision trees.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show non-sequential or grouped information with an emphasis on related pictures. The top shapes are designed to contain pictures.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show hierarchical relationships progressing horizontally and grouped hierarchically. Emphasizes heading or level 1 text. The first line of Level 1 text appears in the shape at the beginning of the hierarchy, and the second and all subsequent lines of Level 1 text appear at the top of the tall rectangles.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show proportional, or interconnected, or hierarchical relationships with the largest component on the top and narrowing down. Level 1 text appears in the pyramid segments and Level 2 text appears in shapes alongside each segment.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show hierarchical relationships progressing from top to bottom and grouped hierarchically. Emphasizes heading or level 1 text. The first line of Level 1 text appears in the shape at the beginning of the hierarchy, and all subsequent lines of Level 1 text appear to the left of the tall rectangles.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show overlapping relationships in a sequence. Works best with Level 1 text only.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to represent a continuing sequence of stages, tasks, or events that can occur in any direction.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show containment relationships. Each of the first three lines of Level 1 text correspond to the upper left text in the shapes, and Level 2 text corresponds to the smaller shapes. Works best with minimal Level 2 lines of text. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to represent a continuing sequence of stages, tasks, or events in a circular flow. Each shape has the same level of importance. Works well when direction does not need to be indicated.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show two opposing ideas, or ideas that diverge from a central point. Each of the first two lines of Level 1 text corresponds to an arrow. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show hierarchical information or reporting relationships in an organization. The assistant shape and the Org Chart hanging layouts are available with this layout.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show grouped or related information. The small shapes on the upper corners are designed to contain pictures. Emphasizes Level 2 text over Level 1 text, and is a good choice for large amounts of Level 2 text.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. The rectangular shapes in the background are designed to contain pictures.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show non-sequential or grouped blocks of information. The top shapes are designed to contain pictures and pictures are emphasized over text. Works well for pictures with short text captions.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show information illustrating a process or workflow. Level 1 text appears in the circular shapes and Level 2 text appears in the arrow shapes. Works best for minimal text and to emphasize movement or direction.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show multiple groups of information or steps and sub-steps in a task, process, or workflow. Level 1 text corresponds to the top horizontal shapes, and Level 2 text corresponds to vertical sub-steps under each related top-level shape.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show proportional, interconnected, or hierarchical relationships. Text appears in the rectangular shapes on top of the pyramid background

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show the relationship to a central idea. Emphasizes both information in the center circle and how information in the outer ring of circles contributes to the central idea. The first Level 1 line of text corresponds to the central circle, and its Level 2 text corresponds to the outer ring of circles. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show relationships to a central idea in a cycle. The center shape can contain a picture. Level 1 text appears in the smaller circles and any related Level 2 text appears to the side of the smaller circles.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show both overlapping relationships and the relationship to a central idea in a cycle. The first line of Level 1 text corresponds to the central shape and the lines of Level 2 text correspond to the surrounding circular shapes. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. Maximizes both horizontal and vertical display space for shapes. Does not emphasize directionality.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or a sequence of stages, tasks, or events in a circular flow. Emphasizes the interconnected pieces. Each of the first seven lines of Level 1 text corresponds to a wedge or pie shape. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. Emphasizes Level 2 text, since each line appears in a separate shape.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show containment, proportional, or interconnected relationships. The first nine lines of Level 1 text appear in the triangular shapes. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts. Works best with Level 1 text only.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show groups of information or steps in a task, process, or workflow. Circular shapes contain Level 1 text, and the corresponding rectangles contain Level 2 text. Works well for numerous details and minimal Level 1 text.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a downward progression through stages. Each of the first five lines of Level 1 text corresponds with a rectangle. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show groups of information built from top to bottom, and the hierarchies within each group. This layout does not contain connecting lines.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show grouped or related information of equal value. The first Level 1 line of text corresponds to the top shape and its Level 2 text is used for the subsequent lists.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show interrelated or overlapping information. Each of the first seven lines of Level 1 text appears in the rectangular shape. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts. Works well with both Level 1 and Level 2 text.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to represent a continuing sequence of stages, tasks, or events in a circular flow. Emphasizes the arrows or flow rather than the stages or steps. Works best with Level 1 text only.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show the relationships of four quadrants to a whole. The first line of Level 1 text corresponds to the central shape, and the first four lines of Level 2 text appear in the quadrants. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show grouped or related information of equal value. Works well with large amounts of text.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or steps that trend upward in a task, process, or workflow. Each of the first five lines of Level 1 text corresponds to a point on the arrow. Works best with minimal text. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow that move toward a common goal. Works well for bulleted lists of information.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. Maximizes both horizontal and vertical display space for shapes. Places more emphasis on the interrelationships among the shapes than on direction or movement.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show groups of information or steps in a task, process, or workflow. Works well with large amounts of Level 2 text. A good choice for text with a main point and multiple sub-points.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show several groups of information, especially groups with large amounts of Level 2 text. A good choice for bulleted lists of information.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show non-sequential or grouped blocks of information. Works well for lists with long headings or top-level information.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow, or to emphasize movement or direction. Emphasizes Level 2 text over Level 1 text, and is a good choice for large amounts of Level 2 text.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show sequential steps or tasks that depict a plan or result. The last Level 1 line of text appears after the arrow. Works best with Level 1 text only.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show non-sequential or grouped blocks of information. The small circles are designed to contain pictures.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show non-sequential or grouped blocks of information. The small shapes on the left are designed to contain pictures.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow from top to bottom. Works best with Level 1 text, since the vertical space is limited.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show overlapping relationships. A good choice for emphasizing growth or gradation. Works best with Level 1 text only. The first seven lines of Level 1 text correspond to a circular shape. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
The process of customizing the look and feel of a product to support marketing or promotion of another company.
A classification of words, labels, tags, etc. into groups based on similiarities.
The set of policies, roles, responsibilities, and processes that are established in an enterprise to guide, direct, and control how the organization uses technologies to accomplish business goals.
A formula giving the roots of a quadratic equation.

Not able to be delivered to an intended recipient. If an e-mail message is undeliverable, it is returned to the sender with information added by the mail server explaining the problem; for example, the e-mail address may be incorrect, or the recipient's mailbox may be full.
A company that provides services or content for its customers.
The on-screen representation of the phone keypad or dial pad on the device.
A type of personal identification number (PIN) for the SIM card, consisting of 4 digits, that is used to gain access to your mobile phone.

A piece of hardware that supports multiple discrete capabilities, such as audio, mixer, and music, on a single card. This device is sometimes treated as a bus that can be enumerated to locate the devices on that bus.
To expose a virtual disk to the user, backed by a file.

The administrative task of making remote resources available to its users, setting policies that control how users will connect, how they will find the remote resources, and what settings users will connect with.
A feature that provides an interface for acquiring rich metadata in order to support showing device detail information in the Device Center and the Device Stage.
A .cab file that can only have one locale support and that provides all the hardware display components in order for your device information to be shown in the Control Panel.
A .cab file that can only have one locale support and that provides all the hardware display components in order for your device information to be shown in the Control Panel.
To uninstall all software on a computer and reinstall a new Windows image.
An easy-to-use troubleshooter that helps find and fix program compatibility issues.
A small pop-up window that informs users of a non-critical problem or special condition in a control.
The physical material on which computer data is stored.
A category of sensor that collects biometric data for a variety of applications.
A category of sensor that may use all or some of the following applied stimulus to detect movement: ultrasound, infrared, heat and vibration.
A biometric sensor that analyses your eye retina to recognize or authenticate identity.
A category of sensor that can respond to an applied stimulus by generating an electrical signal.
A category of sensor that is used for mechanical measurement of force, scale, pressure, strain, etc.
A category of sensor that tracks environmental changes such as temperature, atmospheric pressure, humidity, wind speed and wind direction.
A type of sensor that can determine without physical contact if an object/person is nearby, or can be used to measure the distance between the object/person and the sensor device.

A type of sensor (such as a proximity sensor) that uses radio frequency identification (RFID) for a numerous purposes, such as identification of physical items, automatic log on, location of people, etc.

A type of sensor (such as a proximity sensor) that uses radio frequency identification (RFID) for a numerous purposes, such as identification of physical items, automatic log on, location of people, etc.
A category of sensor that responds to a pre-defined amount of light.
An Internet site that provides a collection of products and services developed by Microsoft partners for Microsoft Office users.
To remove a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetooth–enabled devices.
A view mode in Internet Explorer that determines whether content is rendered as if users were viewing it in a previous version of Internet Explorer.
An Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) 802.11 wireless network in which Service Set Identifier (SSID) suppression is enabled.

A feature that prevents Internet Explorer from storing data about your browsing session. This helps prevent anyone else who might be using your computer from seeing where you visited and what you looked at on the Web.
The feature that blocks third-party web content that could potentially track someone's web activity.

A form of IIS authentication in which IIS accepts client-certificates used to prove the client's identity. Using this form of authentication, IIS can optionally map a client certificate to a Windows user account by using an internal mapping table or Active Directory.

An authentication method where a Kerberos authentication server grants a ticket in response to a client computer authentication request that contains valid user credentials. The client computer then uses the ticket to access network resources.

A command prompt that is run in a privileged administrator security context that allows actions that would normally be restricted. Without elevation, command prompts in Windows Client and Windows Server run in a restricted state.
The link group that includes links to the About Hotmail webpage, the What's New webpage, and so on.
The Windows Live service for event planning and invitations.

The link that appears above an incomplete content set and leads to the full list of items. For example, when a content module displays items 1–6, a "View all" link in line with the module label leads to a webpage that lists all items. The items that are available in preview are redundantly available in the list of all items, which may be paginated.
A contribution or feedback left by someone viewing content on a site. Someone who views a space, photos, or files can leave a comment, if permissions allow it.
A computer that belongs to a homegroup.
A troubleshooter that helps find and fix problems with viewing computers or shared files in a homegroup.
To group together multiple windows of the same application under a single button on the taskbar’s taskband.
A feature that allows the user to digitally alter a picture to increase or decrease the sharpness of focus.
An organizer used to add, uninstall, and search for desktop gadgets.
A program that helps make the text on your screen easier to read for long periods of time.
A virtual device created by System Restore that is needed to set a system restore point.
A zoom out gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving towards the other finger at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A zoom-in gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving away from each other at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A zoom-in gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving away from each other at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A software or device that helps control your home smart devices automatically.

An input device used chiefly for identification purposes that reads information that has been magnetically encoded, usually in two tracks, on a plastic card, such as a credit card or an employee badge.
A notebook that is smaller in size and lighter in weight than a full-sized notebook, while retaining the same functionality.
A gallery containing thumbnail views of open application windows.
A primary storage device based on solid-state memory, such as flash memory, that provides nonvolatile storage with benefits of performance, reliability and power saving.

A termination in which a proxy server terminates an SSL request and then forwards the request to a Web server by using HTTP. In this case, alternate access mappings can be configured to return these requests using SSL, thus maintaining secure communication between the client and the proxy server.
A node that makes cached data available to clients needing to retrieve the data.
The process of maintaining backup files and putting them back onto the source medium if necessary.

termGrp.term: creu copi wrth gefn ac adfer

descripGrp.descrip: A streaming technology that quickly installis Office over the Internet, internal networks, local file systems, or from offline media.
To apply a marker to content or items (like photos or text) to identify certain types of information.
The process of finding, organizing, and displaying information, particularly by electronic means.
An authoritative source for an attribute value that can flow its value to other destination directories and systems.

A COM-based multimedia platform and infrastructure for digital media in Microsoft Windows. It focuses on content protection, audio and video quality, and interoperability for digital rights management (DRM).

A COM-based multimedia platform and infrastructure for digital media in Microsoft Windows. It focuses on content protection, audio and video quality, and interoperability for digital rights management (DRM).
A calendar for a group.
A method of blocking access to websites based on their content. For example, In Windows Live Family Safety, parents can specify a filtering level, such as Strict or Basic, for their child.
A person authorized to manage and make certain changes to a group, such as to approve a membership request.
An audio or video file that you rent from an online store, typically for a monthly fee.
A troubleshooter that performs common maintenance tasks in Windows, such as cleaning up unused files and shortcuts.
A troubleshooter that helps find and fix problems about hardware and devices.

A search location exposed via .osdx templates and made possible via the OpenSearch technology. It connects the local search indexer to a remote index and provides the end user with the ability to search for files on a Web site or on an intranet site from within Windows.
A Web site from Microsoft which provides solutions for the top issues about Windows Update or Microsoft Update, and enables you to contact a support professional.

A feature that allows users to build business logic in a new and easy-to-use authoring environment. The declarative, macro-style logic will run on client and server and includes both UI-level and data-level actions.
A feature that provides one-click filtering controls that make it easy to narrow down the portion of a data set that's being looked at.
A miniature chart that can be inserted into text or embedded within a cell on a worksheet to illustrate highs, lows, and trends in your data.
An Outlook Calendar view in which each calendar is listed vertically (not side-by-side). This view is optimized for viewing a schedule for a group and scheduling a meeting for a group.
A feature that converts each slide in a presentation into a single image and rebuilds a new, compressed PPT presentation that can easily be shared, but not edited.
A viewer that allows users to display Excel workbooks on a phone’s browser. A file is rendered as an HTML page with sufficient fidelity to convey important data or charts and illustrations.
A viewer that allows users to display Word documents on a phone’s browser. A file is rendered as an HTML page with sufficient fidelity to convey text and images on a small screen.

A Windows Media Player (WMP) specific feature that allows you to use the Internet to access music, pictures and videos available on your home network. The feature must be activated on at least two computers in order to work.
A numeric keypad that is part of a device, is displayed on a device, or is in a computer program that you use to enter information in the context of a phone call.

An icon that is attached to an event and that is viewable in someone's calendar. Depending on the calendar view, a charm may appear next to an event title, or may be the only visual representation of an event on a calendar day.
A traditional graphics plotter that uses pens to draw on paper. Pen plotters use one or more colored pens, either fiber-tipped pens or, for highest-quality output, drafting pens.
The part of an e-mail address that identifies a user or an account on an e-mail system.
An e-mail message that is sent by a notification activity.
A part of a schema that defines the representation of a resource in ILM "2".
A procedure by which a user's password can be changed to a known value, in situations where the user has forgotten or lost their password.
A view that shows all of the resources on a project and their work over time. This makes it easy to rearrange work, schedule new work, and manage a team's load.
A feature that allows the application of tags to individual Outlook items to specify retention policy for that message, conversation or other item.
A user interface implemented by a software application via a component of a web server, such as IIS.

A group of people someone communicates and shares with on Windows Live. Someone's network includes people they've added to their profile, to their Messenger contacts, or both. People in someone's network can see information about their latest activities in the what's new list, and may see other information, depending on permissions settings.
To permit someone else to perform an action. For example, to let someone else see your online status, send you messages, or see your public Messenger information.
A navigation button used to return to recently visited Web pages in Internet Explorer and other internet browsers.
A staging area that contains representations of selected objects and attributes in a connected data source.
The data store that is used by ILM to contain the aggregated identity information from multiple connected data sources, providing a single global, integrated view of all combined objects.

Information that describes the current location of a computer. The location is entered manually in Default Location, and can be used by programs to determine the location of a computer when a location sensor is unavailable.

A software system that retrieves information from a source data store and synchronizes (pushes) to a target data store. Examples of synchronization engines are the ILM 2007 and FIM 2010 synchronization engines, and the service that synchronizes data rows in the SQL Server Express database with objects in the Microsoft Office Outlook data store.
To refuse to accept a file or message.
The initial user reference guide or piece of documentation for using a device or feature.
A set of components and services that enable users to access their Exchange mailboxes through the Outlook Web Access application.
A term that can be added to a search to filter the results by a specific property (for example, by author). Relevant search filters appear under the search box in any open folder.
A collection of Internet Protocol subnets, usually used to connect a group of computers that are physically close to each other.
A set of sign-in credentials (username and password) for an Active Directory account.
The identity of a user, which can be used to grant access to resources or authority to perform certain tasks.
A type of corruption that affects the data in the Windows heap, such as damages caused by a buffer overrun, writing to a stray pointer or a double-free.

A soft keyboard that is displayed with a different set of settings by default (larger buttons, bigger size, etc.) when you launch the Tablet PC Input Panel with touch. This is to facilitate touch input.

A two-way device provided by a cable provider that enables some one-way digital CableCARD-based consumer electronic devices such as high-definition DVRs and Media Center PCs to access digital cable channels delivered using switched digital video.
A small, affordable laptop that is designed to perform a limited number of tasks such as web browsing and e-mail.
A real-time, physical action applied to an object, in which multiple contact points are used simultaneously.

A device used to write CD-ROMs. Because a disc can be written only once on these machines, they are used most commonly to create CD-ROMs for data archives or to produce CD-ROM masters that can be duplicated for mass distribution.
A Web analytics report that identifies terms that should become Best Bets.
A Web analytics report that identifies the Best Bet terms and how they are utilized by the system.
A feature that allows administrators the ability to backup and replicate their configuration.
A feature that ensures that all components of a file are preserved, even if they are supported only by the rich client and not viewable in Web Companions.
A feature that simplifies the task of creating new SharePoint data. It makes it easier for users to enter free-form information or add photos, Web Parts or files to a SharePoint page.
Protocol that standardizes the link aggregation process among different vendors.
Protocol that standardizes the link aggregation process among different vendors.

A team site template that provides group collaboration capabilities based on standard business practices. Integrated functions include a group calendar, Whereabouts, Announcements, Phone Call Memo, and Schedule and Reservations.
A feature that collects and logs SharePoint health indicators and usage metrics for analysis and reporting purposes.
The heading for information about the time at which something was added, changed, or re-posted.
A customizable page that launches with Windows Live Messenger and features a summary of news and weather, allows a customer to preview their Windows Live Mail inbox and search the Internet.
The title of the window in which the Windows Live Messenger Today page is displayed.
A text box where someone enters the e-mail addresses of the primary recipients of an e-mail message.

A set of features that enables users to improve the quality of their images with just one or two clicks. Galleries help the user optimize characteristics such as brightness, contrast, color, and sharpness.
A feature that enables Tablet PC users to convert an ink drawing to a standard OfficeArt shape, which can be formatted with colors and effects exactly as if it were inserted using “Insert Shape.”

A feature that enables presenters to capture all the elements of a live presentation, including narration, slides, mouse clicks, A/V playback, and laser pointer highlights. The user can select which presentation aspects to record.
A map view created from aerial photos that shows buildings, roads, and geographical features.

A slide show mode that displays content in a manageable window that can be resized and features navigation buttons. This mode is optimized for reviewing presentations, allowing users to get the full experience, complete with animations and media, while performing other tasks, such as taking notes.

A feature that allows users to easily add links to content within other content (e.g. pages, sections, section groups) and provides quick navigation through these links. The feature operates in the same manner that links work in wikis.
A feature that highlights new or changed content in a shared notebook that the user has not yet read.
A high-level linear representation of a project schedule that can be easily formatted, annotated, and copied and pasted from Project into other Office applications.
A feature that identifies the author of unread new or changed content in a shared notebook.
A task pane that helps form designers to build and manage custom business rules for use in their forms.
A pre-defined table style that allows users to change the look and feel of a form.
A feature that allows form designers to select from a gallery of pre-built rules to make their forms dynamic.
A pre-defined layout that users can select for their InfoPath form sections. Options include single column, two-column, three-column, and four-column layouts.
An environment in the InfoPath client that enables users to fill out forms (as opposed to designing them). It must be used if the forms to be filled out are not browser-compatible.
A Web Part that implements Web chart controls to visually display information in a variety of chart types in SharePoint.
The combination of hardware (touchscreen or touchpad) and software elements that provides a way to control programs by touching multiple points on the screen simultaneously.
A system table that captures failures and other events for Access Services.
The name given to the Macintosh operating system, beginning with version 7.5 in September 1994, when Apple started licensing the software to other computer manufacturers.
The street address or geographical coordinates of a user, and (by way of extensions) of the user’s computer or devices.
To save the user's work on a continuous basis, so that it is not necessary to save manually.

A feature that allows users to see conflicting appointments directly from Mail view without having to switch to Calendar view. Makes it much easier for users to decide to accept or decline a meeting invite that conflicts with an existing meeting.
A feature that is inactive in Office Web Apps, but that is present when the content is opened in the rich client.

descripGrp.descrip: A Microsoft Office Online application that enables users to upload, view (in full fidelity with animations and transitions maintained), share, and edit PPT files in a Web browser, as well as create basic presentations using only the Web client. They can also take those PPT presentations and embed them in other Web applications, like blog postings or other Web sites.
A gallery of effects that users can apply to images to create a customized, artistic look.
A gallery of effects that users can apply to videos to create a customized, artistic look.
A specification according to which each open document occupies its own window in the UI, though only a single instance of the program application is running.
A specification according to which each open document occupies its own window in the UI, though only a single instance of the program application is running.
A view that allows users to read a document, but not to edit it.
A view in Web Companions and Applications that is optimized for editing a document, and looks like the traditional document view in the client application (i.e. contains full Ribbon).
A flexible bounding box that contains the notes that you type or paste on a page.
A feature that enables users to interact with back-end (LOB) data from within the Office Suite and SharePoint.
A tag used to identify a person in a photo.

The heading for the tags that identify people in a photo. This heading is used for the group of all people tags used in someone's photo gallery, and for the group of people tags in an individual photo.
The feature that allows users to stream music, images or videos to a specific device on their home network.
To enter information by means of the keyboard or other input method.

In computer systems, a reduction in level of performance or service. Degradation in microcomputer performance is indicated by slow response times or frequent pauses for disk access because memory is insufficient to hold an entire program plus the data the program is using.
A software component or service that can be used to issue a claim during sign-in operations and to display, resolve, and provide search capabilities for claims in a card selector.
A feature that enables low-impact upgrades by allowing users or administrators to have more control over when the UI transitions from one version to the next.
A type of conditional formatting that is configured within Microsoft SQL Server Analysis Services.
A site element that stores and displays a collection of data that team members and other site users can share.
A site element that stores and displays a collection of data that team members and other site users can share.

A feature that offers improved reliability by throttling client requests and notifying SharePoint administrators when performance is in jeopardy. It monitors parameters such as available memory, number of requests in the queue, and wait times, and rejects incoming requests if performance values cross predefined thresholds.

A unique identifier that represents a specific user, application, computer, or other entity, enabling it to gain access to multiple resources, such as applications and network resources, without entering credentials multiple times. It also enables resources to validate requests from an entity.
A wiki that allows people across a company or organization to capture and share knowledge using a solution that is integrated into and enhanced by their SharePoint environment.
A video clip that has been inserted into another file or Web page.
An audio clip that has been inserted into another file or Web page.
A feature that supports referential integrity between two lists via the lookup field.
A feature that allows IT pros and developers to upgrade features such as UI, lists, content types, actions, and workflows.
A standard control that resembles a notebook and lets the user navigate different sections of information without leaving the current element on the screen.
The ability to view data or navigate to or within a physical or virtual computer environment.
An account holder who is a family member, but not a parent, and who has limited use of the Internet. Children can view their own settings, but they can't change them.
An account holder who is the primary administrator (parent) and the family members they manage.
To join or combine thereby increasing the quantity or size of something.
To adjust the action or aspects of a group of items, typically done more than once.
A text box in which someone types words to begin a search.
A Web analytics report that provides information on the most popular searches.
A Web analytics report that provides information on the number searches performed.
A Web analytics report that provides information about storage usage trends.
A resource management method that prevents an application from overshooting its allocated budget of computer resources, including CPU, memory, disk I/O, and network I/O.
A troubleshooting tool used for per-page performance testing.
An approach that packages together all content deployable to SharePoint -- list templates, list instance, site template, files and declarative workflows.
A feature that allows a view to be created from multiple lists of stored data.

A “software-plus-services” platform and experience that enables PCs and other devices to “come alive” by making them aware of each other through the Internet, enabling individuals and organizations to manage, access, and share their files and applications seamlessly on the Web and across their world of devices.
The value that is to be searched for in a document or any collection of data.
A UI or media segment that can display on top of or play concurrently with another UI or media segment.
To return to a stable condition after some error has occurred. A program recovers from an error by stabilizing itself and resuming execution of instructions without user intervention.
A collection of statistics that indicates the degree to which a service meets performance, usage, and other demands for the service.

A set of rules that defines security permissions for a collection of assemblies by associating attributes of those assemblies, such as location and signature, with a set of code access security permissions.

A set of rules that defines security permissions for a collection of assemblies by associating attributes of those assemblies, such as location and signature, with a set of code access security permissions.

A component that monitors and collects statistics about a system. Those statistics can be compared to a set of thresholds to assess system performance, identify and resolve problems, and perform other diagnostic and administrative tasks.
A feed that provides information, notifications and updates based on people, documents, and tags you are following.
A feed that provides information, notifications and updates based on people, documents, and tags you are following.
A synchronous event whose handler runs completely before the action that raised the event starts.
A mapping between file name extensions and HTTP request handlers that enables Web hosting applications to determine which handler responds to requests for specific types of files.
A script-based applet that is stored as a favorite or bookmark in a web browser, or is accessed through a hyperlink on a webpage.

The process of associating a feature with a site definition, without modifying the site definition itself or using code routines. The associated feature is added automatically to new sites that are based on that site definition.
A collection of statistics that indicates the degree to which a computer, server farm, or server cluster meets security, capacity, performance, usage, and other demands.
The link to the form where a user can report violations of the terms of use. Contextually, it's understood that the abuse in question is poor conduct, such as obscene language or threats.
A control on a page or master page that can be replaced with another control or content.
A control that can be used to set the properties for and to manipulate Web Parts on a Web Parts page.
A relationship in which a feature is activated automatically when another feature is activated or a feature must be activated manually before another feature can be activated.
A text-based, data interchange format that is used to transmit structured data, typically in Ajax Web applications.
A text-based, data interchange format that is used to transmit structured data, typically in Ajax Web applications.
An operation that requires more resources than are allowed by a threshold, based on the number of items or amount of information that is processed during the operation.

An extensible programming model and components that can be used to design and implement custom applications for common business processes, such as document approval. Components include version control, tracking, and reporting.

The object that is used to initiate any actions with the client-side object model. It is the primary entry point for the client object model, and the primary object for coordinating requests against corresponding objects in a site collection.
A server-side code routine that is called when a feature is activated, deactivated, installed, uninstalled, or upgraded on a computer, server farm, or server cluster.

A statistic that indicates the degree to which a computer, server farm, or server cluster meets a specific demand for that configuration. It also indicates which log information to copy to a central location for review.
A content type that inherits settings from a base content type that was designed for any type of SharePoint list item.

descripGrp.descrip: A custom solution that can be deployed to a site by a site collection administrator, without approval from the farm administrator. Without that approval, the solution has full access to the immediate site and restricted access to system resources and other sites.

A persistent container that defines and stores instructions for a job to be run on a server, server farm, or server cluster. To run, a job must have an associated job definition, and a definition must be associated with a service or a Web application.
A dedicated, administrator-level user account that performs scheduled administrative tasks.
A compressed file that can be deployed to a server farm or a site. It can contain assemblies, resource files, site and feature definitions, templates, code access security policies, and Web Parts.
A custom keyword or description and shortcut to a Web page or item on a SharePoint site or the Internet. All of these tags can be viewed, managed, and shared by using My Site.
A collection of features that can be used to store and share comments, shortcuts, descriptions, and other information about Web pages and items on a SharePoint site or the Internet.
A reserved time for performing administrative tasks on a computer, server farm, or server cluster.
An administrative setting that limits the number of query results for SharePoint lists, sites, and site collections that contain a large number of items.
A reserved time for performing large, resource-intensive queries for a computer, server farm, or server cluster.

A solution package that contains only a DLL that stores localized versions of strings in another solution package. After a language pack is deployed to a site, users can display the corresponding user interface in that language.
An area for storing comments about a Web page. A note board can appear on a Web page or in a separate dialog box. The notes can be viewed, managed, and shared by using My Site.
The Microsoft SQL Server, MSDE, or WMSDE database that stores health monitoring and usage data temporarily, and can be used for reporting and diagnostics.
A statistic that indicates the degree to which a computer, server farm, or server cluster meets usage demands for that configuration.
An installation package that the user downloads from http://download.live.com/?mkt=en-us.
The main landing or start page on Windows Live.
The button next to a search box that someone clicks to search for something.

The shared service that securely stores credential sets for external data sources and associates those credential sets to identities of individuals or to group identities. This service can be used to support a variety of solutions. For example, the stored credentials can be leveraged by certain applications to enable single sign-on.
To remove an item from public view.
Feedback about any content, page, or site that is provided using social bookmarks, tags or comments.

A set of features that provides data analysis and reporting on Web traffic, search, and SharePoint assets. This information can be used to tailor systems to meet users’ needs, optimize how they use and discover information, and to create targeted content.

A set of features that provides data analysis and reporting on Web traffic, search, and SharePoint assets. This information can be used to tailor systems to meet users’ needs, optimize how they use and discover information, and to create targeted content.
The status menu item that makes it appear to the user’s contacts that he or she is currently offline.
A process that restricts the flow of data.
The file name extension of a comma-delimited text file.
The file name extension of a dynamic-link library.
A feature that allows members of the Administrator site group to create subsites off of their Web sites.
The file name extension of a Web page that is an Active Server Page.
The process by which organizations find, retain, and preserve electronic documents related to a legal action.
A collection of files, settings, databases, and auxiliary information that is packaged as a file structure or as a compressed file for deployment.
A telecommunications standard that lets users send and receive messages that include rich text, images, audio, and video.
The Windows Live service that lets someone set up dynamic photo collections or other media sources to stream into a digital photo frame, or any RSS-enabled device.
A feature that supports automatic eDiscovery based on matches against a fixed search query.
The file name extension of a data file that stores your messages and other items on your computer.
A feature that enables users to modify dashboard views by changing the subset of data that is displayed in reports or scorecards.
A desktop app that enables WYSIWYG editing, offline editing, and preview functionality.
A desktop app that enables WYSIWYG editing, offline editing, and preview functionality.
The web browser toolbar that provides quick access to Windows Live services, plus optional features to customize the browsing experience.

The Windows Live service that enables a user to create a personal website where they can create and update a blog, and share their photos, music playlists and more, to connect with friends, family, or the online world.
